 Wrong. I own half a stake in an experimentla ethanol project. Even using the new and imporved enzyme production methods, the only way you get to 32 cents per gallon is by applicaiton of a $1 per gallon subsidy fromt he government and by discounting the cost of feedstock transportation (which is incredibly expensive because it is such a low density feedstock). Every report issued by such projects (mine included) doctors the numbers in an attempt to make the technology appear viable. Real production cost (to the pump) from our operation is $3.85 per gallon (stated production cost is 41 cents per gallon). The cheapest real production cost in the country is $3.21 per gallon (their stated cost is 32 cents per gallon). The reality of the situation is that we scam the numbers in order to continue pulling governmetn grants. Acquisition of grants is the only place you make money in the fuel ethanol market.
 
 Additionally, as you scale up such operations, there is an energy return threshold that you reach where it becomes even more expensive to produce than smaller quantities. It is also worth noting that corn is heavily subsidised, so the true cost of fuels may be as much as 2x recognised numbers.
 
 In order to replace half of the oil we use for fuel with ethanol, we would have to plant the entire states of kansas, oklahoma, nebraska, iowa, south dakota, and missouri, in corn crops exclusively for ethanol production. The entire state of Nevada and Arizona would have to be tranformed into giant processing facilites. Nevada and Arizona are no great losses, but the other sates liste provide over 80% of the food we eat, so we would have to find som way to make up that difference.
 
 BUT, like fuel cell technology (which is a loser in the end as well), as long as the general public believes that ethanol is a viable source fo energy and a possible solution ot our energy problems, the government will continue to subsidize it, which will make it a proftable investment at the private level, even if it is a net loss to the public.
